recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: To warm up your legs and improve your turnout, try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions., Releve variations: Work on strengthening your calves and ankles with releve exercises. Try doing single-leg and double-leg releves in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as releve passe exercises to help prepare for the pique turn., Arabesque balances: Work on improving your balance and control by practicing arabesque balances. Start with a low arabesque and gradually work your way up to a higher arabesque position., Spotting exercises: Practicing spotting exercises can help improve your balance and control during the pique turn. Try doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, and gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns., Flexibility stretching: Stretch out your muscles before practicing pique turns to help prevent injury and improve your flexibility. Focus on stretching your legs, hips, and back, and incorporate stretches for your shoulders and arms as well. for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start with your feet in first position, with your heels touching and your toes turned out. Make sure your weight is evenly distributed between both feet and your core muscles are engaged to help with balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn., Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. To challenge yourself, try doing multiple turns in a row and experiment with different arm positions. for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on flexibility, additional exercises could include Pigeon pose: Stretch your hips and glutes with pigeon pose. Hold the pose for 30 seconds on each side, and try different variations to increase the stretch., Forward fold: Stretch your hamstrings and lower back with a forward fold. Hold the pose for 30 seconds and try different variations, such as grabbing onto your ankles or using a yoga block for support., Downward-facing dog: Stretch your shoulders, hamstrings, and calves with downward-facing dog. Hold the pose for 30 seconds and try different variations, such as pedaling your feet or lifting one leg up at a time..

Chaine Leaps is a series of jumps in which the skater alternates between the front and back legs.. For practicing Chaine Leaps as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Chaine turns, Skips, Leap preparations for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start in B-plus position., Perform a chaine turn., Push off the back leg, leaping forward., Land on the front leg, bending knees., Repeat with the opposite leg. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on flexibility, additional exercises could include Pigeon pose, Forward fold, Downward-facing dog.

Jazz Contraction is a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.. For practicing Jazz Contraction as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Pelvic tilts, Cat-cow stretch, Seated forward bend for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Bend knees slightly., Curve spine forward, contracting core., Drop head down, keeping neck aligned., Slowly return to starting position. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on flexibility, additional exercises could include Pigeon pose, Forward fold, Downward-facing dog.
